Accidental release prevention and emergency response policy:

The L.S. Starrett Company (Starrett) operates the heat treat process with a goal to minimize the potential and impact of releases and process safety incidents through adherence to legal requirements, effective management systems, procedures, personnel training and emergency response planning.

Stationary source and regulated substance:

The L.S. Starrett Company (Starrett) stores up to 66,528 pounds of propane at the 121 Crescent Street site in its 18,000 gallon propane storage tank for heat treating and general building heating.

Propane is a flammable substance which is specifically listed in the EPA Chemical Accident Prevention (CAP) provisions of 40 CFR §68.130 with a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.  Facilities that store propane in excess of 10,000 pounds for use other than fuel or for retail sale are subject to the CAP provisions.  Since storage of propane at Starrett exceeds the 10,000 pound threshold, and the propane is used for heat treating (not exclusively building heat), Starrett is subject to the CAP provisions.

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:

Starrett has established a process safety management program to prevent the release of propane from the Starrett facility and provides resources to achieve this specific goal.  The elements of the process safety management program are contained in the various sections of a written Risk Management Plan, maintained by Starrett.  This Risk Management Plan is in addition to other established environmental, health and safety programs, which have been developed and implemented to protect employees, the public and the environment.

Overall, management is committed to safety by being personally involved and committed to the goals of zero injuries and loss incidents.  Individuals assigned the various roles and responsibilities for the successful implementation of the process safety manage

ment program are provided with the resources and authority to achieve the performance with which they have been charged.

Elements of the overall environmental, health and safety program, inclusive of the risk management program, include, but are not limited to:

-	Written environmental, health and safety procedures
-	Written operating procedures
-	Employee training for environmental, health and safety and for safely operating and maintaining the covered process
-	Routine inspections of safety devices and emergency equipment
-	Routine maintenance of process equipment
-	Documentation of process safety information
-	Routine emergency response training
-	Coordination of emergency response with external responders

Five-year accident history:

On October 9, 2017 an employee was burned when exposed to a flash fire at the discharge of the Ipsen Furnace.  The incident resulted in an employee injury and is therefore considered an accident, as defined in 68.42.
The following information pertains to the accident:

-	Date of release: October 9, 2017
-	Time of release: 2:00 PM
-	Duration of release: Instantaneous
-	Chemical released: Propane
-	Quantity released: <5 pounds (estimated)
-	NAICS code: 332212
-	Type of release: Vapor release from inside furnace
-	Release source: Heat treat furnace
-	Weather conditions: Not applicable (inside release)
-	On-site impacts: Employee injury (burns)
-	Off-site impacts: None
-	Initiating event: Loss of burn-off pilot
-	Contributing factors: No flame eye on pilot
-	Off-site responders notified: None
-	Resultant changes made: Addition of flame eye sensors

Emergency Response Program:

The facility has developed an Emergency Response Plan which has been coordinated with the Chairman of the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the Chief of the Athol Fire Department.  The Emergency Response Plan provides the essential procedures for effectively protecting Starrett employees, the public and the envi

The Emergency Response Plan addresses the following:

-	Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases;
-	Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures;
-	Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance;
-	Means of reporting emergencies, including a list of persons or departments that can respond to questions;
-	Emergency evacuation procedures, including the function of the facility alarm system and procedures to account for all personnel; and
-	Responsibilities for rescue and medical duties, including notification of outside agencies.

Planned changes to improve safety:

Planned changes to improve safety of the covered process include, but is not limited to:

-	Corrective actions of findings identified during Process Hazard Analyses and Compliance Audits.
-	Additional flame eye sensors and controls for burner systems associated with the heat treat furnaces.
-	Additional routine inspections and preventive maintenance of furnace control systems by an outside contractor.

Registration:

This registration includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR §68.160(b)(1) through (20) to be reported for a Program 3 process.

Offsite Consequence Analysis:

As a Program 3 process with a regulated flammable substance, an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) has been performed for one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario.  The required data from the OCA is contained within this Risk Management Plan. 

Prevention Program 3:

This Risk Management Plan includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR §68.175(b) through (p) to be reported for a Program 3 process.
